definition: lit. veteran of a hundred battles (idiom)/fig. experienced/seasoned
body/life/oneself/personally/one's morality and conduct/the main part of a structure or body/pregnant/classifier for sets of clothes: suit, twinset/Kangxi radical 158
classics/sacred book/scripture/to pass through/to undergo/to bear/to endure/warp (textile)/longitude/menstruation/channel (TCM)/abbr. for economics 經濟|经济[jing1 ji4]
surname Jing
hundred/numerous/all kinds of
surname Bai
to fight/fight/war/battle

sentences.english: He was a much experienced veteran general.
sentences.chinese: 他是一位身經百戰的宿將。

sentences.english: She shakes her head wearily, like a battle-hardened wedding veteran.
sentences.chinese: 她像一個身經百戰的婚禮老手一樣疲倦地搖搖頭。

sentences.english: The senior hero who has lived through hundreds of battles is held in the greatest respect.
sentences.chinese: 這位身經百戰的老英雄深受大家的尊敬。

sentences.english: Richard was a veteran of many battles.
sentences.chinese: 理查是個身經百戰的老兵。

sentences.english: He fought many battles, and took the strong holds of all, and slew the kings of the earth.
sentences.chinese: 他身經百戰，攻佔了許多要塞，斬殺了各地的君王。

definition: to fight/to exchange blows
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions
to charge and break through enemy lines
fight a battle of words/cross verbal swords
rigorous schemes and deep foresight (idiom); astute and circumspect
scoundrel/rogue/bully/villain
manner/style/panache
to throw one's life in for/to haplessly give one's life for/to sacrifice oneself torturously working for another or for a group/to pour in one's utmost effort/to shed one's last ounce of strength for
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
to prevail upon/to coax
fight to the death/desperate struggle
peer competition/to function as rivals/to make claims as an equal
equestrianism/horsemanship
venturing from one's thatched hut for the first time (idiom)/young and inexperienced/novice/greenhorn
lit. single spear and horse (idiom); fig. single-handed/unaccompanied
